ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Methodologies of comparative jurisprudence; intellectual and textual history of Jewish and Islamic law.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Legal sources and texts were always grounded in and abstracted to legal theory, which made for a very engaging and enlightening class. Source sheets were a great model for this kind of class, although I would've appreciated if they were also posted online. Run like a law school class, so not much participation; more discussion might have been nice.

Professor David is very knowledgeable on the the subject and the classes are nicely structured but I wish there had been more of an opportunity for discussion. I did enjoy engaging with primary sources during clads each week.

Readings are great, as are the texts we discussed in class. Professor David isn't the most engaging lecturer, and he mostly talks through the two-hour seminar slot, so just make sure that if you're taking the class, it's because you're really interested in the material, because you'll only enjoy it if the material is what's driving it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, if Prof. David is back at Yale.

I think the topic is extremely interesting, and Professor David is a really smart guy with a lot of important insights. But you have to take the class because you're interested in the subject matter, otherwise you'll definitely get bored really quickly. It's a very chill class -- very little work other than the readings -- so don't worry about it from that perspective.
